title: First Life Appears
description: The earliest evidence of life on Earth appears in the form of prokaryotic cells, single-celled organisms without a nucleus.

title: Great Oxidation Event
description: Cyanobacteria begin producing oxygen through photosynthesis, dramatically changing Earth's atmosphere and enabling complex life.

title: First Eukaryotic Cells
description: Eukaryotic cells evolve with a nucleus and organelles, representing a major step toward complex multicellular life.

title: First Multicellular Organisms
description: The first multicellular organisms appear, allowing for specialization of cells and more complex life forms.

title: Ediacaran Biota
description: The Ediacaran period sees the first complex multicellular organisms, soft-bodied creatures that represent early animal life.

title: Cambrian Explosion
description: A rapid diversification of life occurs, with most major animal phyla appearing in the fossil record within a few million years.

title: First Land Plants
description: Plants begin colonizing land, evolving from aquatic ancestors and transforming terrestrial ecosystems.

title: First Land Animals
description: Arthropods become the first animals to successfully colonize land, paving the way for terrestrial ecosystems.

title: First Vertebrates on Land
description: Amphibians evolve from fish ancestors, becoming the first vertebrates to walk on land.

title: First Reptiles
description: Reptiles evolve from amphibians, developing amniotic eggs that allow reproduction away from water.

title: Permian-Triassic Extinction
description: The largest mass extinction in Earth's history wipes out 90% of marine species and 70% of terrestrial vertebrates.

title: First Dinosaurs
description: Dinosaurs first appear and begin to dominate terrestrial ecosystems for the next 165 million years.

title: First Mammals
description: Mammals evolve from synapsid ancestors, initially small and nocturnal, surviving alongside dinosaurs.

title: First Birds
description: Birds evolve from theropod dinosaurs, developing feathers and flight capabilities.

title: First Flowering Plants
description: Angiosperms (flowering plants) evolve, eventually becoming the dominant plant group on Earth.

title: Cretaceous-Paleogene Extinction
description: An asteroid impact triggers mass extinction, wiping out non-avian dinosaurs and many other species.

title: Mammals Diversify
description: With dinosaurs gone, mammals rapidly diversify and fill ecological niches, leading to modern mammal groups.

title: First Primates
description: Primates evolve, developing forward-facing eyes, grasping hands, and larger brains.

title: Human-Chimpanzee Split
description: The evolutionary lineages of humans and chimpanzees diverge, leading to the hominin line.

title: First Hominins
description: Early hominins like Australopithecus walk upright, a key adaptation for human evolution.

title: Genus Homo Appears
description: The genus Homo first appears with Homo habilis, characterized by tool use and larger brains.

title: Homo Erectus
description: Homo erectus spreads across Africa, Asia, and Europe, using fire and more sophisticated tools.

title: Homo Sapiens Evolves
description: Modern humans (Homo sapiens) evolve in Africa, with advanced cognitive abilities and complex culture.

title: Humans Leave Africa
description: Homo sapiens begin migrating out of Africa, eventually populating the entire globe.

title: Behavioral Modernity
description: Humans develop symbolic thought, art, complex language, and sophisticated tool-making techniques.

title: Agricultural Revolution
description: Humans begin domesticating plants and animals, transitioning from hunter-gatherer to agricultural societies.
